bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, February 22, 1937

div1.p: Hench thanks Hutchison for the Rovensky letter. Hench would like to meet Kissinger and question him about the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, February 22, 1937
div1.opener:
February 22, 1937
Dr. Ralph Hutchison
Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pennsylvania
My dear Hutch:
div1.p:
Thanks for sending Mr. Rovensky's letter. It sounds en-
couraging. I have not heard from Lord Dawson yet nor has Dr.
Will. We will doubtless hear shortly.

I am on the trail of the address of Kissinger, one of the
three human volunteers who received malaria, in the original
yellow fever work. I am finding out his address for my own
curiosity and in my inquiry I am making, of course, no mention
of you at all.

It is quite probable that the presence of a layman re-
ceiving honors or at least attention would distract from
the honor you are paying Lazear and the living physicians
but I am curious to know where he lives as I should like to
know something about him. I understand that he has frequently
“told the story of the yellow fever work” and if I can, I
should like to meet him some time.

Mary and I leave Monday for Indianapolis and Florida.
Mother is going along as I told you. If my mail contains
any pertinent information I am asking Miss Newton, my
secretary, to send it on to me and I will write to you at
once.
div1.closer: Yours sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:FN
